skill.name: webapp-testing
skill.description: Toolkit for interacting with and testing local web applications using Playwright. Supports verifying frontend functionality, debugging UI behavior, capturing browser screenshots, and viewing browser logs.
skill.summary: Toolkit for interacting with and testing local web applications using Playwright. Supports verifying...

security_audit.summary: Official skill with standard Playwright automation examples and a server lifecycle helper. No risky patterns are present in the reviewed files.

content.user_title: Test local web apps with Playwright helpers
content.value_statement: Local web apps are hard to validate without stable browser automation. This skill provides Playwright patterns and helper scripts to test, inspect, and log UI behavior.
actual_capabilities: Start one or more servers and wait for ports before running a command
Run Playwright sync scripts to navigate, click, and fill fields
Capture browser console logs and save them to a file
Discover buttons, links, and inputs on a page
Automate static HTML via file URLs and take screenshots
limitations: Requires local servers to be reachable on the specified ports
Example scripts require you to supply URLs, selectors, and file paths
Provides helper scripts and examples, not a full test framework

use_cases.title: Validate UI flows
use_cases.description: Run local UI checks and verify navigation, forms, and buttons during development.

use_cases.title: Debug client issues
use_cases.description: Capture console logs and screenshots to diagnose frontend errors on a local build.

use_cases.title: Learn Playwright basics
use_cases.description: Use simple scripts to explore element discovery and page interaction patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Smoke test local app
prompt_templates.prompt: Start my local server on port 5173 and write a Playwright script that visits the home page, waits for networkidle, and verifies the main button exists.

prompt_templates.title: Find UI elements
prompt_templates.prompt: Use Playwright to visit http://localhost:5173, list all visible buttons and the first five links with their href values.

prompt_templates.title: Capture console logs
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Playwright script that captures console logs while clicking the Dashboard link and saves them to a log file.

prompt_templates.title: Static HTML automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Automate a local HTML file using file URL, fill name and email fields, submit the form, and take before and after screenshots.

output_examples.input: Inspect the local app and list key UI elements after it loads
output: Found 3 buttons: Login, Sign Up, Help

best_practices: Run `scripts/with_server.py --help` and use it as a black box helper
Wait for `page.wait_for_load_state('networkidle')` before inspecting the DOM
Close the browser at the end of the script
anti_patterns: Inspecting the DOM before the page finishes loading
Using vague selectors without verifying visibility
Leaving browser processes open after automation

faq.question: Is this compatible with my local stack?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with any local web app reachable in a browser.

faq.question: What are the limits of the scripts?
faq.answer: They are examples and helpers, so you must add your own checks.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my test runner?
faq.answer: Yes, call the scripts from your runner and manage ports as needed.

faq.question: Does it send my data anywhere?
faq.answer: No, the scripts run locally and do not transmit data.

faq.question: What if the server does not start?
faq.answer: Check the port, command, and timeout, then rerun with a longer timeout.

faq.question: How does it compare to full E2E frameworks?
faq.answer: It provides Playwright patterns and helpers, not full reporting or assertions.
